qas.question: What is a USB packet's end called?
What can skew due to hubs add?

answers.text: as much as one bit time before the SE0 of the end of packet

qas.question: What can this extra bit result in?

context: A USB packet's end, called <a0_0>EOP (end-of-packet)<a0_0/>, is indicated by the transmitter driving 2 bit times of SE0 (D+ and D− both below max.) and 1 bit time of J state. After this, the transmitter ceases to drive the D+/D− lines and the aforementioned pull up resistors hold it in the J (idle) state. Sometimes skew due to hubs can add <a1_0>as much as one bit time before the SE0 of the end of packet<a1_0/>. This extra bit can also result in a <a2_0>"bit stuff violation<a2_0/>" if the six bits before it in the CRC are 1s. This bit should be ignored by receiver.
